elements.text: PART ONE
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
1. $™$INT. UNIVERSITY PHYSICS LAB
FX: A STUDENT PROTEST IS GOING ON OUTSIDE, CONTINUING
SPORADICALLY THROUGHOUT.
Down, down, down, down — down with the Laws of Physics! Two, four, six, eight - we can’t afford to cogitate! Don’t dehumanize the humanities!
FX: CROSS TO CLICKING, BUZZING, HUMMING SOUNDS OF PHYSICS
DEPARTMENT LAB. MORE OUTLANDISH NOISES (RINGING AND BUZZING TONES, PERHAPS) EMANATE FROM A RUDIMENTARY TIME MACHINE.
I do wish that rabble outside would put a sock in it. I’ve hardly been able to concentrate all day because of their racket.
I suppose they’ve got a right to protest.
Not right outside the physics department. If they’ve got a problem they should take it to University House, tell the Vice Chancellor...
They’ve occupied University House already. You’re out of touch, my sweet.
I’ve been busy, ‘my love’. (BEAT) You see... I’ve made a breakthrough, John. I think I’m almost there.
Really?
I think I’m close to a trial run.
You wouldn’t just be saying that as an excuse, would you, Philippa?
Of course not! An excuse for what?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 3
For not coming along. Tonight. To the dinner?
Oh, that. I’m sorry, John. I can’t. I just can’t. This is a vital moment...
So is this dinner. It’s a big deal for me, Philippa.
It’s just a conference dinner.
People are coming from all over the world for this conference. My conference. My big important conference that’1ll put the History Department of the University of Frodsham on the global academic map.
Yes, well. I still can’t make it.
So I’m to attend the dinner and the opening ceremonies and the drinks by the campus duck pond alone, am I? What are they all going to think?
That your wife has a career of her own, perhaps?
It would be nice to have you there, that’s all. Showing your support.
You don’t need me, John. You’1l have those fusty old historians eating out of your hand. They love you.
Do you really think so?
You'll wow them. Now go on. Get out of my lab. Maybe I’1l pop over for a drink at the duck pond, after you’ve all fed your faces. All right?
I suppose that will have to do.
FX: RISING NOISE FROM STUDENT PROTESTERS.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 4
That lot are getting even rowdier.
Yes, I hardly fancy my chances, making it safely across to the
conference centre... (EXITS)
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 5
2. EXT. CAMPUS — PHYSICS DEPT
FX: CONTINUING CHANTS BREAK UP AS BLEAK OPENS DOORS OF BUILDING
AND TRIES TO SLIP AWAY.
(JEERING) Oi! There’s old Bleak! He’s on the Funding Committee!
One of the money men! Grab him!
(JOSTLED) Do you mind letting me pass?
Well, well. Professor John Bleak, isn’t it?
Call off your dogs, Barry.
Which class of yours did I take, Professor Bleak?
I beg your pardon?
‘Revolutions and Reactionaries’, wasn’t it? Well, now you can see what I learned.
You’ve certainly got them all riled up.
Because of your iniquitous allocation of funding. They’re closing down Philosophy because of you lot on the Committee.
I’m not discussing university policy with a bunch of layabouts! Let me through at once. I have a conference to organise.
You’ve given all the money to Physics and Chemistry. What about the Humanities, Professor?
I am a part of the Humanities, you stupid boy! I am a Professor of History! I am on your side!
You’re not on my side, you old goat.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 6
How dare you! You’re making this personal.
(TO OTHERS) All right — let him through. Let him get to his conference...
Thank you.
FX: GRUMBLING AND FURTHER JEERS AS BLEAK’S FOOTSTEPS CARRY HIM
AWAY.
(TO SELF) Off you go, Professor. Go and wallow in your ancient history. That way, maybe you’1ll not even notice what’s going on right under your nose...
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 7
3: EXT. CAMPUS — SQUARE
FX: PROTESTORS’ CHANTING RESUMES FROM SOME DISTANCE AWAY, AS
TARDIS MATERIALISES ON CONCRETE FLAGSTONES. DOORS OPEN AND ITS CREW EMERGE.
England, 1983. Time to stretch our legs, I think.
Good. Feels like we’ve been cooped up in there for ages.
Where are we, exactly?
There’s a sign. ‘The University of Frodsham.’
FX: DOCTOR CLOSES TARDIS DOOR.
Ah, yes. One of the most august seats of learning in the North.
Not exactly Oxbridge, though, is it?
You’re such a snob, Turlough.
Well, just look at it! It’s all concrete and glass...
What’s the conurbation over there?
Down the hill? That’s Merseyside, Nyssa. What a view.
Yes, a lovely industrial wilderness! Terrific.
(HEARING PROTESTORS OFF) Is there a riot going on?
Probably just students protesting about... something or other.
You’ve brought us here for a reason, haven’t you, Doctor?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 8
Well, as a matter of fact — there is something I need to check, while we're here...
FX: PRODUCES A SMALL HANDHELD TIME TRACER, AND ACTIVATES IT —
Oh, and out he comes with a thingumajig!
What’s that for?
Are you scanning for something?
Let’s try — this way, I think.
FX: ALL WALK OFF.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 9
4. INT. CONFERENCE CENTRE — FOYER
FX: MUZAK PLAYING. GLASS DOORS SWOOSH OPEN AND BLEAK HURRIES
INDOORS, HUFFING AND PUFFING CROSSLY. DOORS SWOOSH SHUT BEHIND.
(COMING OVER) John! Whatever’s the matter? You look all discombobulated.
It’s those blasted protestors, Molly. Spouting off about issues they don’t even understand. Funding allocation is a highly complicated process! Don’t they even realise [that]
Never mind all that now. We’ve enough problems of our own.
What’s the matter? What’s gone wrong?
Nothing, except the rest of the conference packs and badges won't be back from the printers until tomorrow morning —
What?!

. and the overhead projection unit has overheated, again; oh, and some of the rooms in the guest suite have been double- booked; yes, and all the trains from Manchester are delayed tonight. But apart from that...
It’s a disaster...!
No, it isn’t. And you must get a grip on yourself. If you don’t look calm, everyone else will start panicking...
But don’t you see? This has to be a success. This is my final chance at securing the future of the history department. You know they want to close us down...
Sssh. I won’t hear defeatist talk. This conference will be a brilliant success. So — pull yourself together.
I will. I will, Molly. You’re very good.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 10
Nonsense. I’m the Dean’s secretary. I’m simply doing my job.
Where would I be without you?
Now, come on. We’ve must get ready to welcome our delegates. How was your wife... (ARCH) .. by the way?
Busy. Too busy to come to dinner.
We might need to fill a few seats at the meal tonight. (WALKING OFF) I’1l1 look at the seating plan and shuffle folk around.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 11
5: EXT. CAMPUS — BY CONFERENCE CENTRE
FX: FADE UP. DOCTOR WALKING AHEAD WITH BLEEPING TRACER,
COMPANIONS FOLLOWING.
What a curious environment to study in. Rather unwelcoming, really.
Oh, I don’t know. I was at college for a bit. It wasn’t unlike this.
You went to college? I thought you were an air hostess.
I still had to learn stuff!
(OFF, AT CONF CENTRE DOORS) Hello, there! Can I help you?
(CALLING OVER) Quite alright, thank you!
FX: MOLLY WALKS QUICKLY TOWARDS THEM THROUGH:
Doctor, she’s coming over.
So you'd better switch off that whatsit of yours.
Yes, thank you, Tegan.
FX: DOCTOR SWITCHES OFF TIME TRACER.
You’re not students. Are you?
Certainly not.
Only in the sense that one never stops learning. Hello, I’m the Doctor. And you are?
Molly Wright. Dean’s secretary, School of History. Sorry, but I thought you looked lost.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 12
Funny, that.
You’re here for the conference, of course.
Conference?
‘The Heirs of Ethelfrid: Perspectives on the Queens of the Dark Ages’?
Snappy title.
I’m one of the organizers. I’m afraid we’ve been having some problems with guest arrivals and room bookings and so on. And I’ve lost the party from the University of Wollongong.
Wollongong!
Don’t get excited, it’s a dump.
Ah, so that’s you!
(IMPROVISING) This is, ah, Dr Tegan Jovanka. World expert in Queens of the Middle Ages.
Really?
Sssh, Turlough.
(FX: FLICKING OVER PAPERS ON CLIPBOARD) Dr Jovanka? That’s not the name I’ve got down here...
Last-minute replacement. But Dr Jovanka’s work in the area really is second to none.
Oh! Well, in that case — you’d best follow me.
FX: ALL HEAD OFF INTO BUILDING.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 13
6: INT. CONFERENCE CENTRE — FOYER
FX: DOORS OPEN, DOCTOR & CO ENTERING. MUZAK PLAYING — BUZZ OF
CONVERSATION FROM DELEGATES.
(OFF) Yes, in fact I’ve got a paper coming out addressing that exact quandary next year...
(OFF) This is a very charming atrium, is it not, Professor Fester?
(OFF) Oh indeed. Of course, they’ve put all their cash into the infrastructure. It’s all show, you know.
(STOPPING) Exciting-looking bunch in here.
What are you up to, Doctor?
I’ve got a feeling, that’s all. And it’s a conference. You always learn interesting things at conferences. That’s what they’re for.
But you’ve got Tegan pretending to be someone she isn’t...
Oh, she’1ll love the attention, you’1ll see.
(COMING UP) Here is your conference pack, Dr Jovanka, including vouchers for the conference dinner this evening. Will your colleagues all be attending, too?
(TAKING PACK) Uh... yes. Sure. They’re sticking with me.
Right. If you’re replacing Professor Stimpson from Wollongong, then you’1ll be giving your paper at 9.15 tomorrow morning in the Mother Theresa suite upstairs.
Well, I’1l look forward to that, thanks.
We all will.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 14
My pleasure. Now, I must pop off and attend to the other delegates. There is a free welcoming schooner of sherry in the main atrium, and there you may mingle with your fellow experts.
Hear that, Tegan? Free sherry.
(MOVING AWAY) Cheerio!
Doctor, I’m going to murder you.
Well, we’re here now, so let’s go and mingle. I’m rather fascinated by all of this.
What? By a bunch of dowdy old duffers in tweed and polyester standing around gossiping?
It’s a gathering of intellectuals, investigating their ancient past — that’s right, isn’t it, Doctor?
Specifically, investigating Ethelfrid of Mercia. There’s a poster of her, look.
She appears to have been quite formidable.
Who the heck was she?
One of the great lost queens of the Dark Ages. The daughter of Alfred the Great.
. who burnt the cakes!
Exactly. Might I have a look at that conference pack?
(HANDING IT OVER) Here, I don’t want it. C’mon, Turlough, let’s get some drinks. (THEY WALK OFF)
FX: DOCTOR RUMMAGING IN HER FOLDER OF PAPERS.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 15
(OBLIVIOUS) It’s really quite fascinating, you know. And local, too. This whole part of the country was Mercia, [back in the...]
I’m listening, Doctor. Even if the others aren't.
(OBLIVIOUS) Mm?
They’ve gone, Doctor.
(HURT REALISATION) Oh.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 16
7. INT. CONFERENCE CENTRE — ATRIUM
FX: BACKGROUND, ECHOING BUZZ OF CONVERSATION
(WALKING) I don’t even like sherry. Oh, this is a nightmare. What’s he playing at?
(PULLING HER OVER) Tegan, look at this.
Some old sword in a case.
It’s gold, I think. (TOUCHING CASE) It must be worth something.
Turlough!
(BUTTING IN) I wouldn’t touch that if I were you. The case is alarmed.
(SHIFTING BACK SHARPLY) Is it?
My, er, colleague was just admiring the sword. Weren’t you, Turlough?
The University of Manchester have been kind enough to let us borrow it for the duration of our conference. It is a great honour.
It’s very beautiful.
As far as we can determine, this is the very sword that the Queen of Mercia wielded against her enemies.
Wielded? You mean, personally?
Naturally. Ethelfrid was a warrior queen. She fought off the Danes to the north, and also the southerners from Wessex. She was a fearsome woman.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 17
Speaking of which — this is Dr Tegan Jovanka.
All the way from Wollongong.
Really? Professor John Bleak. Your host at this conference.
Pleased to meet you.
Of course, Dr Jovanka already knew all that stuff about the Queen of Mercia fighting her enemies with a sword. She’s an expert, you know.
Yes, well — it’s, er, time I gave my welcoming talk. (MOVING OFF) So if you’ll excuse me...?
Turlough, you utter —
FX: INTO TEGAN’S MIND. QUICKLY FADE UP SOUNDS OF SWORDS
CLASHING; CRIES AND SCREAMS — A DARK AGES BATTLEFIELD.
Tegan? Tegan! What’s the matter with you?
FX: BATTLE NOISE CUTS OUT ABRUPTLY.
Ohh...!
What’s wrong?
I dunno! I was staring at the sword... at the jewel in the pommel... and I heard this noise...
Probably just your stomach rumbling, I know I’m starving. Come on. Let’s grab some of those canapés they’ve got going round.
AS THEY WALK OFF, FADE TO:
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 18
8: INT. CONFERENCE CENTRE — ATRIUM (A FEW MOMENTS LATER
FX: CHATTY BUZZ OF THE DELEGATES — BLEAK BLOWING ON MIC — MOLLY
CLAPPING HER HANDS FOR QUIET.
Quiet, please! Professor Bleak would like to say a few words!
FX: POLITE APPLAUSE — SOME LIGHT-HEARTED CHEERS

(INTO MIC) Good evening, friends and fellow scholars. I am delighted to see you all here, assembled at the University of Frodsham — at one of the very sites where the Lady of Mercia actually lived, some ten centuries ago. [From the hill on which this campus stands, you can see the selfsame wild Northern landscape that our revered Queen Ethelfrid once ruled with a staff of iron and a sword of gold. ]
(SOTTO, AS TEGAN APPROACHES) There you are!
(SOTTO) We’ve just met that Bleak bloke.
(SOTTO) Goes on a bit, doesn’t he?
(SOTTO) Quiet, Turlough. This is interesting stuff.

This weekend we are convened in order to air our findings and theories about this most mysterious of monarchs. We have in our midst academics who have come from as far afield as Australia to be with us...
(SOTTO) That’s you he’s talking about.
(SOTTO) If only he knew from just how far afield we’ve come.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 19

[And perhaps, through our combined efforts,] in listening and debating and sharing our knowledge, we will inch a little closer to solving some of the mysteries about Queen Ethelfrid. We know that she ruled the kingdom of Mercia, stretching from North Wales to the coast of Yorkshire; and also that, by bringing about the union of several unruly northern regions, she was, arguably, the founder of England as we now know it. But we know next to nothing about how she was deposed, or what happened to her descendants. Hopefully our work here this weekend will go some way to rediscovering the truth. May we all raise our glasses to.. the Lady of Mercia!
(MUMBLED TOASTING) The Lady of Mercia!
FX: MULTIPLE CHINKING GLASSES. CROSS TO:
Well, if I had a glass I’d raise it...
Well, Tegan? Aren’t you impressed? The Lady of Mercia. She united the whole of northern England against its attackers.
Yeah, great. So Bleak said.
I don’t think Tegan’s all that interested in her forebears.
She sounds like something of a feminist role model to me.
Tegan had a dizzy spell, looking at the sword.
Oh? Are you all right?
I’m fine. It’s just for a moment, I really thought I could hear
the noise of... I dunno, a battle.
Maybe it was the students outside?
FX: CROSS TO MOLLY CLAPPING HANDS.
This way, ladies and gentlemen. Dinner is served!
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 20
8. EXT. CAMPUS — OUTSIDE PHYSICS BUILDING

(TO PROTESTORS) All right, guys. This is going to be uncomfortable, lying on concrete. But we’re doing the right thing! Petitions and daytime protests are all very well — but we’re not gonna quietly go home! We’re staying here all night!
RAGGED, SLEEPY, HALF-HEARTED CHEER
We’re all in this together, right? Come on, let’s get our sleeping bags out.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 21
9: INT. DINING ROOM
FX: CHAIRS BEING SHUNTED ABOUT — CHATTER — TINKLING OF CUTLERY.
(SEATING HIMSELF) Good evening, everyone.
Congratulations on your speech, Professor. Most illuminating.
Was it? I was rather distracted, I’m afraid.
Well, we all found it very interesting.
Charming of you to say so, my dear.
(COMING OVER) There you are, Professor. (ASIDE) You see, John? It’s all going swimmingly now.
(ASIDE) I just hope there’ll be no more glitches. And I wish Philippa was here. She missed my speech and everything.
(ASIDE) I don’t understand — why are you so wound up?
(ASIDE) I’m not... it’s just...
(ASIDE) Have a drink. You were wonderful up there. Inspiring. Queen Ethelfrid herself would be proud.
(ASIDE) There’s a lot at stake.
(ASIDE) I know.
ASIDE) You don’t know how much. (GETTING UP AND LEAVING
Excuse me a moment, Molly dear. And please — best you lay off the sherry, don’t you think?
And you are?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 22
Er, I’m the Doctor. And you must be Dr Angeline Duchamp!
You recognize me-?
No, I read your name badge. But I’m an avid follower of your work.
Merveilleux, Doctor. I am intensely flattered.
(ASIDE, TO NYSSA) Look how he does it. He charms his way in so easily, every time.
You could try it, Turlough.
I am charming! I’m extremely charming.
What will they do if they find out we’re imposters?
They can be pretty brutal, academics, I hear.
Where’s Tegan got to? She’s been gone a long time.
I was just thinking that. I’1ll go and have a look around... (GETS UP AND LEAVES )
Tell me, Doctor — where are you based? Where do you carry out
your research?
Hm? Oh, in the field, mostly. You know. Getting my hands dirty.
Really? But they look so clean.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 23
10: INT. ATRIUM
FX: EARNEST EATING CONVERSATION FROM THE OTHER ROOM. TURLOUGH
STEPS OUT — AND IS GRABBED BY TEGAN.
(PULLED ASIDE) Tegan! What are you doing, lurking behind the displays?
(HISSED) Me lurking! I just stepped out to go to the loo. Now ssh!
(HISSED) You were going back for another look at that sword, weren’t you?
(HISSED) Actually, I wasn’t. But look... someone is...!
FX: BLEEPING OFF AS BLEAK DISABLES ALARM AND SLIDES OPEN GLASS
PANEL ON DISPLAY CASE.
(HISSED) The Professor!
(HISSED) I was just coming out of the Ladies — and there he was, disabling the alarm.
(HISSED) Why’s he got the sword out?
(OFF, HOLDING SWORD, MURMURING) Beautiful. Beautiful...
Isn’t it obvious?
He can’t rob himself, can he?
He said it was on loan from a museum.
FX: BLEAK TAKES SWORD AND SCURRIES OFF.
And there he goes! See - he’s wilfed it, Turlough.
I don’t believe it...
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL)
FX: DOORS OUT OF BUILDING OPEN AND CLOSE.
He’s heading out! I’m going after him.
Tegan, leave it alone! This is none of our business.
Yeah, well, I’m making it mine. Go back to the others don’t like it. (EXITS)
Tegan. Tegan!
FX: DOORS. SHE’S GONE.
Page 24
if you
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 25
11: INT. DINING ROOM
FX: THE DINNER GOES ON.
And these young people — they are your research assistants, Doctor? Your P.H.D. supervisees, perhaps?
Something like that, yes.
They are very fortunate to work with you. But you must have been so young when you began your researches. A prodigy, in fact!
Well, um —
(SEEING TURLOUGH APPROACH) Ah, and here comes another one.
Turlough! Where’ve you been?
(SITTING DOWN) Oh, nowhere, really. What’s that you were saying about me, Dr Duchamp?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 26
12: INT. PHYSICS LAB
FX: TIME MACHINE NOISES AND LABORATORY ATMOSPHERE AS BEFORE —
BUT WITH MORE URGENCY. DOOR FLIES OPEN AND BLEAK HURRIES IN WITH STOLEN SWORD.
Philippa, look! Look what I’ve brought you!
John? What on Earth —
Look, it’s the real thing. The actual sword of Queen Ethelfrid...!
Careful..! You’1ll have someone’s eye out.
How’s that for a test subject, for your first trial run?
You’re not serious.
Deadly serious, my love. Are you?
What do you mean?
If your work is so vital — prove it to me. Here, tonight, in this laboratory!
I think the only person trying to prove a point here is you.

Think about it, Philippa! If your device does all that you think it will — well, we’ll have founded a whole new discipline, won’t we? A perfect union between history and science! Much like our own, hm?
Oh, for goodness’ sake. Did no-one see you take it?
Dinner was on. You know what academics are like when there’s free feed. Please, Philippa. We have to do this, while we’ve got the chance.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 27
I have to admit... its size and antiquity makes it an ideal test subject.
I knew you wouldn’t be able to resist. Where do you want me to stick it? On top of the machine?
Into the hole on the side. There are brackets to hold it in place.
FX: AS BLEAK STICKS THE SWORD IN, STONE BEGINS PROGRAMMING A
CONTROL PANEL.
There. What now?
FX: MACHINE ACTIVATING.
Now, the machine scans the object.
You’re sure it won’t damage the sword?
Al it’s doing is examining the fabric of the thing. Probing the history of the metal itself.
Incredible...
It’s tracing it back into the past.
It’s amazing. And so are you.
Don’t be too quick to congratulate me. The machine hasn’t done anything yet. This whole thing could be an expensive failure.
You won’t fail. I know it. Just think, Philippa... living history!
FX: MACHINE NOISE GOES UP A NOTCH.
We'll see. (SEEING TEGAN AT DOOR) — Hold on, did you leave the lab door open?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 28
Of course not.
Well, then — how did she get in here?
FX: TEGAN STEPS IN, SIGHING.
Rabbits!
Dr Jovanka?!
Who?
She’s from Wollongong.
What’s she doing here?
I was following him, if you must know. I was at his conference, and I saw him stealing the sword and... Hang about, what’s that machine you’ve jammed it into?
A vital part of my wife’s scientific research. The product of years of work by one of the most brilliant minds on campus.
Oh yeah? And what’s it meant to do?
FX: THE TIME MACHINE NOISES GROW EVEN LOUDER AND MORE AGITATED,
AS IF IT IS RARING TO GO.
(PRESSING BUTTONS) Erm... John. I can’t... I can’t seem to... switch Tt Ofte.
My wife has made an astounding breakthrough, Dr Jovanka.
She has?
We are unbelievably honoured to bear witness to this.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 29
(PANICKING) It’s going haywire, John. I don’t know what to do!
Can’t you just switch it off?
That’s what I’m telling you! I can’t..!
Get that sword out of there! It’s priceless, right?
FX: WHILE STONE GRAPPLES WITH SWITCHES AND LEVERS, BLEAK PULLS
AT THE SWORD.
(EFFORT — PULLING) The sword... it’s stuck! It’s fused into the
machine!
JOINING HIM) Here, let me try — (EFFORT
John, get that woman out of here!
We should all get out. That machine of yours is gonna blow..!
What-?
I think she’s right. Leave it be, both of [you]
FX: THERE IS A HUGE IMPLOSION.
SCREAMS
FX: THE SWIRLING NOISE OF THE MACHINE BEGINNING TO TRAVEL
THROUGH TIME. It GOES. BEAT. DEBRIS AND GLASS FALLS.
(GETTING UP) Oh no.. John? Where are you..? (REALISATION) Him the Australian woman — they’ve gone...!
and
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 30
13: INT. DINING ROOM
FX: CHATTER AND TINKLING CUTLERY AS BEFORE.
(EXAMINING PLATE) What is this? Chicken?
Coated in something. With something else on the side.
I suppose it’s better than what comes out of the TARDIS food machine.
I prefer the Food Machine.
(BRIGHTENING) Really? I built that, you know.
Doctor, all this talk of historical mysteries... Aren’t you tempted to simply tell them that you could find out the answers?
Well, you know what I’m going to say to that, Nyssa.
Something to do with not interfering with time, I imagine.
Spot on. Where has Tegan got to?
(EATING) I told you, I’ve no idea.
Now I think of it, Molly went to look for Professor Bleak. He’s been gone a long time, too.
Yes, and the lovely French lady seems to have abandoned us as well.
(EATING) Perhaps everyone thinks we’re boring?
Don’t talk with your mouth full, Turlough.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 31
Poor Tegan. I’ve dropped her in at the deep end, getting her to pretend she’s an expert.
Sometimes I think Tegan could do just about anything.
Even bluff her way through the history of the dark ages?
She comes from the dark ages.
That’s a point. Relatively speaking.

Know what I’d do, if the TARDIS was mine? I’d charge all the professors a whopping great fee and tell them — Come on, then. Pay me, and I’1l take you back to wherever you like, and you can find out the truth.
Luckily you don’t have a TARDIS of your own, Turlough.
Look, here’s Molly now.

STONE: John? What on Earth —
BLEAK: Look, it’s the real thing. The actual sword of Queen Ethelfrid...!
STONE: Careful..! You’1ll have someone’s eye out.
BLEAK: How’s that for a test subject, for your first trial run?
STONE: You’re not serious.
BLEAK: Deadly serious, my love. Are you?
STONE: What do you mean?
BLEAK: If your work is so vital — prove it to me. Here, tonight, in this laboratory!
STONE: I think the only person trying to prove a point here is you.
BLEAK: Think about it, Philippa! If your device does all that you think it will — well, we’ll have founded a whole new discipline, won’t we? A perfect union between history and science! Much like our own, hm?
STONE: Oh, for goodness’ sake. Did no-one see you take it?
BLEAK: Dinner was on. You know what academics are like when there’s free feed. Please, Philippa. We have to do this, while we’ve got the chance.
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 27
STONE: I have to admit... its size and antiquity makes it an ideal test subject.
BLEAK: I knew you wouldn’t be able to resist. Where do you want me to stick it? On top of the machine?
STONE: Into the hole on the side. There are brackets to hold it in place.
STONE: CONTROL PANEL.
BLEAK: There. What now?
STONE: Now, the machine scans the object.
BLEAK: You’re sure it won’t damage the sword?
STONE: Al it’s doing is examining the fabric of the thing. Probing the history of the metal itself.
BLEAK: Incredible...
STONE: It’s tracing it back into the past.
BLEAK: It’s amazing. And so are you.
STONE: Don’t be too quick to congratulate me. The machine hasn’t done anything yet. This whole thing could be an expensive failure.
BLEAK: You won’t fail. I know it. Just think, Philippa... living history!
STONE: We'll see. (SEEING TEGAN AT DOOR) — Hold on, did you leave the lab door open?
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 28
BLEAK: Of course not.
STONE: Well, then — how did she get in here?
TEGAN: Rabbits!
BLEAK: Dr Jovanka?!
STONE: Who?
BLEAK: She’s from Wollongong.
STONE: What’s she doing here?
TEGAN: I was following him, if you must know. I was at his conference, and I saw him stealing the sword and... Hang about, what’s that machine you’ve jammed it into?
BLEAK: A vital part of my wife’s scientific research. The product of years of work by one of the most brilliant minds on campus.
TEGAN: Oh yeah? And what’s it meant to do?
TEGAN: AS IF IT IS RARING TO GO.
STONE: (PRESSING BUTTONS) Erm... John. I can’t... I can’t seem to... switch Tt Ofte.
BLEAK: My wife has made an astounding breakthrough, Dr Jovanka.
TEGAN: She has?
BLEAK: We are unbelievably honoured to bear witness to this.
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 29
STONE: (PANICKING) It’s going haywire, John. I don’t know what to do!
BLEAK: Can’t you just switch it off?
STONE: That’s what I’m telling you! I can’t..!
TEGAN: Get that sword out of there! It’s priceless, right?
TEGAN: AT THE SWORD.
BLEAK: (EFFORT — PULLING) The sword... it’s stuck! It’s fused into the
BLEAK: machine!
STONE: John, get that woman out of here!
TEGAN: We should all get out. That machine of yours is gonna blow..!
BLEAK: What-?
STONE: I think she’s right. Leave it be, both of [you]
STONE: THROUGH TIME. It GOES. BEAT. DEBRIS AND GLASS FALLS.
STONE: (GETTING UP) Oh no.. John? Where are you..? (REALISATION) Him the Australian woman — they’ve gone...!
STONE: and
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 30
TURLOUGH: (EXAMINING PLATE) What is this? Chicken?
DOCTOR: Coated in something. With something else on the side.
TURLOUGH: I suppose it’s better than what comes out of the TARDIS food machine.
NYSSA: I prefer the Food Machine.
DOCTOR: (BRIGHTENING) Really? I built that, you know.
NYSSA: Doctor, all this talk of historical mysteries... Aren’t you tempted to simply tell them that you could find out the answers?
DOCTOR: Well, you know what I’m going to say to that, Nyssa.
NYSSA: Something to do with not interfering with time, I imagine.
DOCTOR: Spot on. Where has Tegan got to?
TURLOUGH: (EATING) I told you, I’ve no idea.
NYSSA: Now I think of it, Molly went to look for Professor Bleak. He’s been gone a long time, too.
DOCTOR: Yes, and the lovely French lady seems to have abandoned us as well.
TURLOUGH: (EATING) Perhaps everyone thinks we’re boring?
NYSSA: Don’t talk with your mouth full, Turlough.
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 31
DOCTOR: Poor Tegan. I’ve dropped her in at the deep end, getting her to pretend she’s an expert.
NYSSA: Sometimes I think Tegan could do just about anything.
DOCTOR: Even bluff her way through the history of the dark ages?
TURLOUGH: She comes from the dark ages.
NYSSA: That’s a point. Relatively speaking.
TURLOUGH: Know what I’d do, if the TARDIS was mine? I’d charge all the professors a whopping great fee and tell them — Come on, then. Pay me, and I’1l take you back to wherever you like, and you can find out the truth.
DOCTOR: Luckily you don’t have a TARDIS of your own, Turlough.
NYSSA: Look, here’s Molly now.
MOLLY: (SITTING DOWN, BREATHLESS) It’s most odd. I can’t find them anywhere. Are you sure you don’t know why Professor Bleak might have gone off with your friend, Mr Turlough?
DOCTOR: Turlough...?
TURLOUGH: (TO MOLLY) I told you, Molly, it wasn’t like that. She was going after him.
NYSSA: Turlough, you knew!
TURLOUGH: Tegan said it was none of my business. I took her at her word.
DOCTOR: (SIGH) What happened?
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 32
TURLOUGH: We both saw him do it. Unbelievable, really. He could have been caught at any moment. And Tegan took off after him. Outside.
MOLLY: I don’t understand. What did he do? The Professor?
TURLOUGH: When he thought no-one was looking, he took the sword of Ethelfrid out of the display case and made off with it.
MOLLY: What?!
TURLOUGH: And Tegan went charging off after him.
DOCTOR: Oh no.
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 33
DOCTOR WHO: TEGAN/BLEAK:
DOCTOR WHO: STONE FLOOR OF A PASSAGEWAY IN THE CASTLE.
DOCTOR WHO: GROUND. DISTANT SOUNDS OF REVELRY AND LAUGHTER.
TEGAN: Prof...? You alright?
BLEAK: W-what happened?
TEGAN: We took a trip. Only this machine of yours looks a bit messed up. Come on, stand up.
BLEAK: I can’t. I feel sick. I feel... Wait a minute. A trip? Where are we?
TEGAN: I’m trying to figure that out. Stone walls. Blazing torches.
BLEAK: This isn’t campus.
TEGAN: Not unless the halls of residence are really ripping off the first year students.
BLEAK: Philippa! Where’s Philippa?
TEGAN: She’s not here, So...
BLEAK: She’s dead. I know it. She was caught in the blast. The whole place must have gone sky high...
TEGAN: I don’t think so.
BLEAK: What would you know about it?
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 34
BLEAK: Listen.
TEGAN: Sounds like a party going on downstairs.
BLEAK: I.. I don’t know how to tell you this, Dr Jovanka...
TEGAN: It’s just Tegan.
BLEAK: But... my wife was working on a kind of.. well, in layman’s terms I suppose one would have to call it a time machine.
TEGAN: Would one, now?
BLEAK: You don’t seem very amazed.
TEGAN: We’re standing in a medieval castle, so...
BLEAK: But.. time itself, Doctor Jovanka. My wife has somehow conquered the fourth dimension.
TEGAN: And dumped us here. Well, bully for her.
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 35
DOCTOR WHO: MOLLY, NYSSA AND TURLOUGH.
DOCTOR: Molly — go back to your delegates. Finish dinner.
MOLLY: But the Professor...!
DOCTOR: We'll find him. We’1ll bring him back.
NYSSA: The Doctor’s right, Molly. You’re in charge of the conference now.
MOLLY: All right. But let me know as soon as you find out what’s going on.
MOLLY: HEAD OFF AT PACE.
DOCTOR: (WALKING) Turlough — show me which way Tegan went.
TURLOUGH: (WALKING) Tegan followed him across this square as far as I could make out. And up those steps into that building there.
NYSSA: (WALKING) Department of Physics. What are all those people doing, laying on the steps?
TURLOUGH: (WALKING) Sleeping, I think. I suppose they must be the protesters. It’s like a refugee camp.
DOCTOR: (WALKING) We’d better not wake them. I’ve got a very uneasy feeling about [all this]
DOCTOR: POCKET.
DOCTOR: (STOPPING, PULLING TRACER OUT OF POCKET) ... Ah!
TURLOUGH: What is that bleeping thing of yours, anyway?
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 36
DOCTOR: Time tracer.
NYSSA: You were checking it before, when we first arrived...
TURLOUGH: A time tracer? Really?
DOCTOR: That’s what it’s called.
TURLOUGH: Did you make that yourself, too?
DOCTOR: It’s picking up time distortion on a massive scale.
TURLOUGH: And the source...?
DOCTOR: Straight ahead. The Physics building.
NYSSA: This is why we’re here, isn’t it? It’s not about the conference at all.
DOCTOR: Someone is doing some very dangerous experiments. We have to put a stop to them. But I think we may already be too late!
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 37
BLEAK: Someone’s coming.
TEGAN: A whole load of someones, by the sound of it. Come on, get up. We’1ll have to explain ourselves.
BLEAK: How on Earth do we explain this?
TEGAN: We'll think of something.
ELFWYN: (MARCHING UP) You! Who are you? How did you come to be in this castle?
TEGAN: We can explain...
ELFWYN: We heard the most terrible, unearthly sounds ringing through the air. And now here you are.
BLEAK: (TERRIFIED) Really, we don’t mean you any harm...
ELFWYN: Silence — sorcerer! Guards, seize them!
TEGAN: (SEIZED BY GUARD; DITTO BLEAK) What are you going to do with
TEGAN: us?
ELFWYN: Queen Ethelfrid herself will decide your fate!
ELFWYN: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 38

elements.text: PART TWO
REPRISE:
[..] Guards, seize them!
(SEIZED BY GUARDS; DITTO BLEAK) What are you going to do with
us?
Queen Ethelfrid herself will decide your fate!
17. INT. CASTLE — CORRIDOR [CONTINUOUS]
Ethelfrid-?! The Lady-?!
Aye. My mother. (CALLING) Mother! Mother!
Mother? B-but —
Look smart, Prof. Here she comes.
FX: RUSTLE OF THE QUEEN’S GOWN AS SHE APPROACHES — HER
FOOTSTEPS AND THOSE OF TWO TROOPERS ACCOMPANYING HER.
Daughter? These are the interlopers?
A sorcerer and his apprentice, aye!
My Lady. I-i-is it really you?
Shut up, Bleak. You’re babbling.
I am Ethelfrid of Mercia. Queen of the Northern Lands and protector of the Northern peoples. And I am beset on all sides, by enemies from abroad and within.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 39
It’s an honour to meet you.
Elfwyn, are you sure about these people? But for their apparel, there seems nothing so outlandish about them.
Thanks, your Maj.
(OUTRAGED) What did you say?!
Elfwyn, never mind all that. I hate standing on ceremony.
This is incredible. I didn’t dare dream... Oh, Philippa! If only you were here!
Alright, calm down. (TO ETHELFRID) I apologise for my... friend, Majesty. We’ve come a long way to be here, he’s a bit overcome.
But where did you come from? And how did you get inside the castle?
FX: 2 x TROOPERS ADVANCE MENACINGLY, CLATTERING IN ARMOUR.
Hey, mind where you’re pointing those swords!
Elfwyn, tell your men to stand down.
There could be danger, mother. We don’t know what these strangers intend. And that... thing. Is it a means of torture of some kind?
We will learn nothing by mere speculation!
Listen to them, Tegan! Talking... like.. like people!
Pardon my daughter. She is still in a very belligerent mood. Only yesterday she and my forces achieved a great victory here in Derby.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 40
(EXCITED) Derby, that’s right!
We have taken back not just this castle, but the region entire. We have driven the Danes back to the north. It has been a long, hard struggle — so tonight, we can afford to be gracious.
But mother...
And for once we needn’t disembowel strangers at first sight!
But what if they are sorcerers?
Black magic — ha! This is the tenth century, my dear. We’re not in the time of the Druids, you know.
(ASIDE) Oh, I wish I had my camera...
(ASIDE) It’s not the time for taking snaps.
FX: ELFWYN CROSSES TO TIME MACHINE.
But what is this instrument they have brought...?
Give it a rest, Elfwyn. Can’t we drop our guard for a bit?
Not for one moment, mother. We must protect you.
Leave that... thing alone. I’1ll have the men throw it out.
Wait! Look what I’ve found...
FX: METALLIC SCRAPE AS ELFWYN YANKS THE SWORD OUT OF THE TIME
MACHINE. GASPS FROM GUARDS.
(GROAN) The sword! Oh no.
Yeah, that’s torn it.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 41
But — but that is —
Your sword, mother. Lying within the instrument these strangers brought with them.
I lost this in battle last year. On the fields of Runcorn, fending off my brother Wessex’s men. It drank thirstily of their blood that day... do you remember?
Aye, and now it is here. What do you think of these strangers now, mother?
P-please, we can explain —
Were you sent by my brother? Are you from the south, come to plague me again?
FX: ODD NOISE FROM THE TIME MACHINE — STARTING UP.
What fresh devilry is this?
The machine’s starting to glow — what’s happening, Bleak?
It’s been activated again...
Maybe because she pulled out the sword?
Elfwyn.. daughter! Get away from that device...!
FX: TIME MACHINE NOISE BUILDS TO A CRESCENDO. CAUGHT IN ITS
FIELD...
SCREAMS
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 42
18: INT. PHYSICS BUILDING — FOYER
FX: EERIE, ECHOING QUIET INDOORS — THEN, GLASS FRONT DOORS
SWINGING OPEN AND THE DOCTOR, NYSSA AND TURLOUGH HURRY INSIDE. BLEEPING FROM TIME TRACER PEAKS AND FADES AWAY.
Why has the tracer gone quiet?
Signal is fading. The distortion has calmed down.
But whoever started it is somewhere in this building?
We could take a floor each until we find them.
What’s so important about this time distortion anyway?
You know perfectly well, Turlough, what can happen when the wrong people interfere with time.
Yes, but there’s no Findecker here, surely?! There could be a perfectly innocent explanation.
No sort of artificial time distortion can be said to be innocent, not in 1983. And if someone here has got a rudimentary time machine working...
That’d be quite an impressive achievement, in an era like this.
Well, I did say rudimentary. But yes, it would have to be someone very clever indeed. And they could do a great deal of damage.
FX: TIME TRACER BLEEPS EXCITEDLY.
Aha! We’re off again! Come on — upstairs!
FX: THEY RUSH OFF, UP STONE STEPS.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 43
19: INT. ETHELFRID’S CASTLE
FX: TIME MACHINE NOISE, AND ELFWYN’S SCREAM, FADE TO NOTHING.
BEAT SILENCE.
Elfwyn...? Daughter...?
I’m sorry. She’s gone.
The machine, too!
Where? Where has she gone?
(SIGHS) This is going to sound crazy, your Majesty — but, well, here goes: —
(INTERRUPTING, PANICKED) The machine’s gone, Tegan! Don’t you see what that means?
Getting back to the twentieth century is the least of our problems right now.
Oh, but my daughter was right about you! Guards — take hold of these sorcerers!
FX: GUARDS SEIZE TEGAN AND BLEAK — STRUGGLE.
Get your hands off me! Leave us alone!
Calm down, Bleak. They’re scared. They could lash out at any moment.
My daughter, taken from me! Oh, Elfwyn — if only I’d listened to you!
Your Majesty... please. It’s not what you think.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 44
Foul witch, do not presume to tell me what to think! Guards — place these creatures in irons, then search every corner of this castle. You must find my daughter!
Oh, for goodness’ sake. Don’t you see? She’s not here any more.
She’s gone to.. another domain, I guess you could say.
Then you will bring her back, from wherever you have sent her.
I don’t think we can do that, your Majesty.
You will find a way. Or I will have you drawn and quartered and burn your living remains into cinders!
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 45
20: INT. PHYSICS LAB
FX: THE ROOM IS QUIET — UNTIL THE DOOR FLIES OPEN AND THE
DOCTOR, NYSSA AND TURLOUGH HURRY IN. TRACER BLEEPS AND FADES INTO BACKGROUND.
Looks like a bomb’s dropped in here.
Who are you? Get out of my lab...!
Hello. I’m the Doctor, this is Nyssa and that’s Turlough.
We’re here to help you.
You're too late. Just get out, will you-?!
Turlough — put the kettle on. Over there, look. I think our friend here’s had a shock.
You can’t fix this with tea!
Turlough, do as the Doctor asks.
(SIGH) Alright-!
FX: TURLOUGH SLOPES OFF SURLILY AND IS HEARD MAKING TEA IN THE
BACKGROUND UNTIL HE RETURNS.
Please. If there’s been some sort of temporal accident, then I promise you, we can help.
Temporal? You know what I’ve been working on-?!
Yes, I do, I’m sorry to say. And I’m not very impressed.
You should be.
Well, I’m impressed — but I’m not very pleased.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 46
Oh, really?
Look, why don’t we begin at the beginning? Like I said, I’m the Doctor.
I’m Stone. Dr Philippa Stone.
And you’ve somehow managed to make yourself a time machine.
Who are you, the Men in Black? Or the Man in Cricketing Whites? Come to close me down?
Not exactly. Please, tell us what happened.
The whole thing went crazy. There was a kind of implosion, and the machine just... vanished. It wasn’t supposed to do that.
No.
We're looking for our friend. Tegan. She’s Australian.
She was last seen running after a Professor Bleak, who’d stolen a Medieval sword?
That was John, my husband. Yes... they were here.
Professor Bleak is your husband?
Don’t sound so surprised, I’m not obliged to take his name.
No. No, of course not.
Things have been rather difficult lately. We’ve both been so buried in our work. Him with his conference, and me with my —
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 47
Time machine.
It sounds so silly when you say it, doesn’t it?
(RETURNING WITH TEA, MUGS CLINKING) Oh come on. Humans can’t invent this kind of technology in the twentieth century. They just can’t!
Quiet, Turlough. You’re giving too much away.
‘Humans-?’ Who are you people?
(CHANGING SUBJECT) You should drink your tea.
Urgh, no thanks — it’s all milky and horrible.
Can’t get anything right, can I?
(PROMPTING STONE) Please, Dr Stone. The Australian woman-?
Dr Jovanka, that was it. She grabbed hold of him. John, I mean. Only he was holding the sword, and the sword was inside the machine, and they all just vanished.
Yes, but where to?
Back in time, obviously. To wherever the sword belonged.
Yes, that’s it.
(DISTRESSED) And now I don’t have the first idea how to get them back...!
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 48
21: INT. CASTLE — CORRIDOR
FX: CASTLE ATMOSPHERICS, AS BEFORE.
(TO GUARDS) Take them to the dungeons!
The dungeons! But you can’t! I’m claustrophobic!
Calm down. I don’t much relish the thought of being locked up either, but...
Please, your Majesty. You must listen to me!
Why should I harken unto you? You’re just another shouty little man, pleading for my attention, claiming to deserve my ear...
But I can help you!
You said you could not.
But I can! I know the future. I know how things will all work out.
I don’t think this is such a good idea...
What is this? Do you claim to be a seer?
No, better than that. I come from the future. I know what will become of you, your Majesty. This land of Mercia, [too!]
Silence! I distrust those who claim to see into the future.
I don’t blame you. The fact is, your Majesty — you’re right. He is a sorcerer.
What-?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 49
Trust me.
I will not suffer magicians in this kingdom of mine. The Danes have already infected this place with their heathen rites. Guards — take him away!
But — what about her?
She told me the truth. A witch would have lied. Now bleat no more — magician!
FX: CLATTER AS GUARDS DRAG BLEAK AWAY.
(DRAGGED OFF) No, please! I’ve a medical condition!
Your Majesty, I beg you. Show this foolish man the strength of your mercy.
Don’t presume that I will not kill him, woman. It is just that I cannot hear myself think for all his prattling on.
Er, right.
Now, let us have an intelligent conversation. Then I shall decide the fate of you both.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 50
22: INT. PHYSICS LAB
FX: DOCTOR PLAYING WITH BEEPING BUTTONS.
Leave the control panel alone! You’1ll only make it worse!
Like I said — we’re here to help.
The machine’s controls seem to be fused.
They froze when the cabinet was propelled into the past.
FX: BURBLING OSCILLOSCOPE TRACE.
Interesting. The oscilloscope would seem to indicate some kind of incoming corporeal event... caught in stasis by the looks of sy ore
What?
Don’t look at me, I’m only the teaboy.
There’s a shadow wave formation — see? That’s a pulse.
A living pulse, caught in limbo. But unless this machine can pick up the signal properly, and provoke a manifestation... whatever, whoever it is, they’re stuck.
So if we can get the controls working again...
We might be able to get Tegan back, yes.
But how? Oh, you might as well go. There’s nothing you can do.
We’re not going anywhere, Dr Stone. Not if there’s a chance of getting Tegan and your husband back.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 51
Tegan or her husband, surely? There’s just one life sign, after all.
Yes, thank you, Turlough.
One of them’s dead? That’s what you’re saying?
Or lost in the time vortex, possibly.
Oh, this is all my fault..!
Well, yes, obviously.
I knew. I knew it wasn’t ready yet. There were safety features to think about. Time could be poisonous, for all we know, and moving through it might be deadly...
Not exactly, but please. Go on.
But John insisted. He kept pushing and pushing...
Your husband was keen for you to succeed.
It was so seductive. Especially to a historian. To me it was about testing out the theory, but to him...
Bleak was more concerned with the machine’s practical applications?
He had a plan... for a whole new school of historical research. Empirical research into the past...!
You mean, actually travelling back into the past and finding things out for himself?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 52
No, no. He didn’t want to go into the past. He wanted to bring the past here. He wanted to bring people out of history, and into this laboratory...
He may have paid the price for his ambition.
He was on the funding committee as well, you see. Up at University House. He convinced them to keep pouring money into the Physics department... into my research...
Hence the protesters outside.
Oh, yes. They thought he was abusing his position.
(FX: IDLY FLICKING SWITCHES) Well, he was, wasn’t he?
Turlough, leave the controls alone.
They think it was all about nepotism and greed. But there was so much more to it...
Yes — something much, much worse than plain old nepotism and greed.
FX: TIME MACHINE CONTROLS START TO COME ALIVE AGAIN.
(WARNING) Doctor...!
It was in the cause of knowledge. All he wanted to do was to shed some light upon the Dark Ages...!
(ALARMED) Doctor...!
(IRRITATED) Yes! — (REALISATION) Have you been playing with those controls?
I think I’ve managed to get the thing going again...!
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 53
(GOING OVER) The signal’s growing in strength.
Incoming corporeal event. I was right! Someone’s coming through!
FX: LOUD, SPIRALLING NOISES — AS THE DEVICE RETURNS TO THE LAB.
There’s a figure forming...!
Yes, but who?
That isn’t Tegan. Or the Professor!
FX: NOISE CUTS OUT AS DEVICE LANDS WITH A THUMP.
BEAT.
Hello, there..! Please, don’t be alarmed.
Where am I? Where have I been brought?
That might take a little while to explain...
Tell me! Elfwyn of Mercia demands to know!
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 54
23: INT. CASTLE — BEDCHAMBER
FX: LOW FIRE IN GRATE. MOANING WIND OUTSIDE.
I will not be able to sleep tonight. Not in this unfamiliar place.
It’s... very nice. As castles go. (SHIVERS) Bit drafty, mind.

It’s a hovel. If my late husband could seen some of the places I’ve slept in the years since he died... he’d be horrified. He promised to keep me in splendour. But in order to keep hold of his kingdom, I have had to live like a soldier. (BEAT) Oh, but never mind all that now. Self-pity ill becomes me, though heaven knows I’ve enough cause for misery.
You and me both.
(AMUSED) Yes. What is your name, sorceress?
Tegan Jovanka, your Majesty.
Now we are alone — (BUT CONFIDENTIAL) — you may tell me the truth, about how you came to be here.
That’s the actual truth, right? Not the truth you’1l allow your men-at-arms to hear you entertain?
You are wise, Tegan Jovanka. The actual truth, of course.
Fair enough. I guess it’s one thing for a Queen to believe in sorcery, but to believe in time travel — well, that’d make you look nuts.
(UNFAMILIAR PHRASE) ‘Time... travel’?
We’re not magicians, me and the Professor. It’s kind of hard to explain, but we’ve been displaced from our own time. From the future.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 55
Have a care. You cannot have a future if I have you killed.

I must convince my people that I am still possessed of the strength to unite this country. But to prove that my strength will endure, I must also show that I might be succeeded by a vital heir.

i'm trying!

Me? (GRABBED BY ELFWYN)

FX: CRACKLING FIRE — WIND MOANING OUTSIDE.
This is a tumultuous time, Tegan Jovanka. My kingdom could splinter and break apart at any moment. Our enemies are everywhere and none of them want a woman ruling over them.

NYSSA: BEAT.
DOCTOR: Hello, there..! Please, don’t be alarmed.
ELFWYN: Where am I? Where have I been brought?
DOCTOR: That might take a little while to explain...
ELFWYN: Tell me! Elfwyn of Mercia demands to know!
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 54
ETHELFRID: I will not be able to sleep tonight. Not in this unfamiliar place.
TEGAN: It’s... very nice. As castles go. (SHIVERS) Bit drafty, mind.
ETHELFRID: It’s a hovel. If my late husband could seen some of the places I’ve slept in the years since he died... he’d be horrified. He promised to keep me in splendour. But in order to keep hold of his kingdom, I have had to live like a soldier. (BEAT) Oh, but never mind all that now. Self-pity ill becomes me, though heaven knows I’ve enough cause for misery.
TEGAN: You and me both.
ETHELFRID: (AMUSED) Yes. What is your name, sorceress?
TEGAN: Tegan Jovanka, your Majesty.
ETHELFRID: Now we are alone — (BUT CONFIDENTIAL) — you may tell me the truth, about how you came to be here.
TEGAN: That’s the actual truth, right? Not the truth you’1l allow your men-at-arms to hear you entertain?
ETHELFRID: You are wise, Tegan Jovanka. The actual truth, of course.
TEGAN: Fair enough. I guess it’s one thing for a Queen to believe in sorcery, but to believe in time travel — well, that’d make you look nuts.
ETHELFRID: (UNFAMILIAR PHRASE) ‘Time... travel’?
TEGAN: We’re not magicians, me and the Professor. It’s kind of hard to explain, but we’ve been displaced from our own time. From the future.
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 55
ETHELFRID: Have a care. You cannot have a future if I have you killed.
TEGAN: I mean, far in the future. Centuries. The machine made it happen. We didn’t choose to come here.
ETHELFRID: Then... this machine, is itself a demon? Or possessed by one?
TEGAN: If you like. We didn’t make it bring us here, any more than we made it take your daughter away.
ETHELFRID: Oh, what to believe? I’m half out of my wits. To have lost Elfwyn, at this crucial time...
TEGAN: Is she your only daughter?
ETHELFRID: Aye. Since my Lord the King died... all those many years ago... we have only had each other. Suddenly I feel so alone. So alone, and so tired...
TEGAN: You look whacked out, if you don’t mind me saying.
ETHELFRID: I have been fighting for so long. When we took this castle earlier, I dared to believe that the day might yet be won — but if word gets out that Elfwyn has disappeared, all could be lost!
TEGAN: I don’t understand, your Majesty.
ETHELFRID: Tomorrow, I must appear in the city of York, to receive a blessing at the Minster. I must be resplendent and triumphant. I must convince my people that I am still possessed of the strength to unite this country. But to prove that my strength will endure, I must also show that I might be succeeded by a vital heir.
TEGAN: Elfwyn!
ETHELFRID: If the people cannot believe in me — in my line — then I fear that my time has come to an end.
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 56
TEGAN: Right. That’s why you needed Elfwyn disappearing like you need a hole in the head.
ETHELFRID: (SLY) Perhaps, though, my daughter may yet reappear...
TEGAN: Perhaps, but I don’t know how.
ETHELFRID: (DECISIVELY) Tegan Jovanka — pledge your allegiance to me, and I will spare your life. Aye, and that of your prattling friend, too!
TEGAN: My allegiance-? (SUSPICIOUS) Why? What do you want me to do?
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 57
DOCTOR: It’s all right. You’re quite safe.
ELFWYN: What is this place...?
DOCTOR: That might be rather difficult to explain. Please, if you’d mind putting that sword of yours aside — [just for a moment]
NYSSA: Doctor, look out!
ELFWYN: Where have you brought me to, demons?
STONE: Please, mind the time machine!
ELFWYN: Answer me, demons! (YELLS; EFFORT...)
STONE: Is she really from the past?
TURLOUGH: It rather seems that way.
DOCTOR: Her surcoat and hose are certainly of primitive manufacture —
TURLOUGH: Yes, thank you for the rundown on Medieval fashion.
STONE: Doctor, do something before she destroys the entire lab!
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 58
DOCTOR: i'm trying!
TURLOUGH: (SHOUTING) Can’t you reverse the machine, and send her back?
STONE: It was your messing with the controls that brought her here! Can’t you?
ELFWYN: Yes — send me back! I don’t want to be here!
DOCTOR: Well, that’s quite understandable. But, like I say, we can only help you if put the sword aside, just for a moment?
ELFWYN: Get away from me, master of demons!
TURLOUGH: Hold on. That sword — that’s Ethelfrid’s, or whatever her name is! The one that Bleak stole!
STONE: Then... she must have seen him! (TO ELFWYN) The man you took the sword from — what happened to him?
ELFWYN: The sorcerer, you mean? In the castle at Derby?
STONE: I don’t know, probably —
ELFWYN: The grey-faced man who cringed, and stammered, and cowered in fear?
STONE: Yes, that’ll be him.
ELFWYN: If my mother has the wisdom of her forefathers, she’ll have scraped the flesh from his bones with a fishknife by now.
STONE: What?
NYSSA: The woman who was with him — what happened to her?
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 59
ELFWYN: I neither know nor care. Release me from this place! Return me to my mother’s side!
DOCTOR: ‘Elfwyn of Mercia’, you said. Your mother, she wouldn’t happen to be —
ELFWYN: Queen Ethelfrid herself, aye!
DOCTOR: Ah. Now that complicates things, rather.
STONE: Then — we succeeded. We brought the past back here, to the
STONE: University!
STONE: TOWARDS THE DOOR.
ELFWYN: If you will not free me from your castle, then I shall fight my way out!
NYSSA: Turlough, stop her! She’s heading for the door!
TURLOUGH: Me? (GRABBED BY ELFWYN)
ELFWYN: (GRIPPING HIS HAIR) You! You have red hair. Are you a Dane?
TURLOUGH: No, no, just a demon. (GASPS AS SHE LETS GO) Thank you. Now —
TURLOUGH: There’s the door. Go on, out you go! Go!
ELFWYN: If you were a Dane, I’d have cleaved your skull in two. (EXITS)
ELFWYN: BEAT.
NYSSA: Turlough, you let her go!
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 60
TURLOUGH: Well, what else was I supposed to do?
DOCTOR: We’d better get after her. Come on, Nyssa!
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 61
ETHELFRID: This is a tumultuous time, Tegan Jovanka. My kingdom could splinter and break apart at any moment. Our enemies are everywhere and none of them want a woman ruling over them.
TEGAN: You said... you’ve got the Danes in the North, and also your own brother’s people after you?
ETHELFRID: I am besieged from all sides, and now my daughter — my heir — is gone. But the people must see their warrior princess, tomorrow, in York — when I appear before the crowd.
TEGAN: Hang on. I think I know what you’re about to suggest.
ETHELFRID: You are much like Elfwyn. The same height, and size, and build. In the kirtle, smock and cape of a woman warrior you will look the very image of my daughter.
TEGAN: I can’t go around impersonating the heir to the throne!
ETHELFRID: Would you rather I had your ‘Professor’ executed?
ETHELFRID: AWKWARD BEAT.
TEGAN: All right.
ETHELFRID: You’1ll do it?
TEGAN: I just hope I’m making the right decision.
ETHELFRID: How could you not be, if it means saving the life of your friend?
TEGAN: He isn’t really a friend. We just got caught up in this together.
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 62
ETHELFRID: You came from the same place, though.
TEGAN: True — but 1983 is all we have in common, I hope.
ETHELFRID: Your future land. Am I really remembered there?
TEGAN: Oh... Of course.
ETHELFRID: And do you also claim to know what will become of me?
TEGAN: (HESISTANTLY) I have a friend, who knows all about how time works...
ETHELFRID: Another ‘wise’ man, like this Professor Bleak?
TEGAN: The Doctor really is wise. Though I’d never say that to his face, of course. He’d say that knowing in advance how things turn out.. well, that could spoil things for everyone.
ETHELFRID: Perhaps I will meet your Doctor one day.
TEGAN: Perhaps.
ETHELFRID: (DECISIVELY) Come, Tegan Jovanka — we must take you to my armourer!
TEGAN: What, now?
ETHELFRID: We will ride to York this very night!
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 63
DOCTOR WHO: DUCKS.
MOLLY: (HERDING PROFESSORS) Now, everyone — this is the free-form socializing section of the evening’s entertainments. Sherry is served. Just don’t get too close to the edge of the duckpond, it is rather dark.
DUCHAMP: Ms Wright? Is there still no sign of Professor Bleak?
MOLLY: Unfortunately not.
DUCHAMP: How regrettable his absence is. Many of us are keen to praise him for the organisation of this marvellous event.
MOLLY: (SARCASTIC) Because he organized the entire thing, obviously.
DUCHAMP: Pardon?
MOLLY: Nothing. Nothing, Dr Duchamp. —
MOLLY: DEPARTMENT — CRIES FROM SUDDENLY WOKEN STUDENT PROTESTORS AS ELFWYN BARGES THROUGH THEIR RANKS.
STUDENT PROTESTORS: (OFF) Hey — what?/ Is it morning yet?/ Get off me!/ Don’t shove!/ OWW! [ETC]
BARRY: (OFF) Here, you! This is an official picket, you can’t break the line!
ELFWYN: (OFF) (KICKING STUDENTS) Get back, you scabious peasants!
FESTER: (SAUNTERING OVER) What on Earth is going on over there?
MOLLY: I don’t know... (READING NAME BADGE) .. Professor Fester, does that say?
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 64
DUCHAMP: But this must be the protesters outside the Physics Department agitating some more? Ahh, it reminds me of Paris, in 1968...
FESTER: Yes, I fear they may be revolting again.
DUCHAMP: My dear Professor Fester, the students are always revolting, no?
FESTER: Oh, I’m a Point Five Reader. I never have to see another student as long as I live.
FESTER: DUCHAMP/FESTER:
FESTER: ELFWYN, WHIRLING SWORD AROUND. PANIC AMONG PROTESTORS.
BARRY: (OFF) Someone’s hurt! Someone’s bleeding!
ELFWYN: (OFF) Get back! Back, I say!
MOLLY: I thought they were just having a sleep-in! It sounds like a riot!
DUCHAMP: Someone should go over there. Professor Fester, perhaps you could go and see what is the cause of all this ‘ullaballoo?
FESTER: Who, me? Well, alright then...
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 65
DOCTOR WHO: — THE CLASH OF HER SWORD AGAINST CONCRETE.
STUDENT PROTESTORS: (DISORGANISED CRIES THROUGHOUT, INCLUDING: ) Move over!/ Stop shoving!/ Has no-one called the police?/ You can’t call the police, you’re an anarchist!/ Oh, Mum!
ELFWYN: Demons! Hobgoblins! Let me pass!
BARRY: Back off, everybody! Let her through!
FESTER: (RUNNING UP) Now, look here! What’s going on? You, young man!
BARRY: We didn’t start it this time! You can’t blame us!
ELFWYN: It seems I must start chopping heads!
FESTER: It’s some kind of madwoman!
BARRY: We thought she was one of your lot.
FESTER: Hardly.
NYSSA: Oh no. Doctor, do something!
DOCTOR: (SHOUTING) Please, someone give the lady room...!
FESTER: (CALLING TO DOCTOR) You — from the Wollongong party!
DOCTOR: I beg your pardon?
FESTER: Who is this dreadful woman?
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 66
ELFWYN: Who am I? I am Elfwyn — Princess of Mercia! And I am here to
ELFWYN: wreak havoc on you all!
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 67
DOCTOR WHO: GLASSES. ‘AHS’ AND ‘OOHS’ FROM ACADEMICS.
MOLLY: Oh, my goodness! Whatever is going on?
DUCHAMP: That woman, she is in period costume! I must say — this really
DUCHAMP: is marvellous, Ms Wright! An historical re-enactment! Professor Bleak really has gone the — ‘ow you say — ‘extra mile’, has he
DUCHAMP: not?
MOLLY: But Professor Bleak didn’t organize any historical re- enactments...!
DUCHAMP: Look at her swinging the sword of Ethelfrid. Superb! Quite, quite superb!
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 68
BARRY: Stand back, comrades! She’s loopy!
ELFWYN: You peasants! You are easy meat!
NYSSA: Doctor, someone’s going to get killed!
DOCTOR: (CALLING) Elfwyn — no! You will not attack anyone here!
ELFWYN: (STOPPING) What did you say?
DOCTOR: I said — I demand that you leave these people alone!
ELFWYN: You presume to tell a warrior princess what to do?
NYSSA: Doctor, be careful —
DOCTOR: Elfwyn — I mean it! Stop this at once!
ELFWYN: I will not!
DOCTOR: Then I defy you! I stand here — and I defy you!
ELFWYN: Then prepare to die, demon master!
ELFWYN: END OF PART TWO
DOCTOR WHO: THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 69

elements.text: PART THREE
REPRISE:
Elfwyn — I mean it! Stop this at once!
I will not!
Then I defy you! I stand here — and I defy you!
Then prepare to die, demon master!
30: INT. PHYSICS LAB
FX: STONE SLAMS DOWN RECEIVER OF 80S-STYLE TRIMPHONE.
Hold on, it’s all gone quiet out there.
Too late, I’ve called the police. Shouldn’t you have gone after your friends?
FX: DOOR FLIES OPEN — BARRY STUMBLES INTO LABORATORY.
Philippa! Are you all right, love?
Barry, you shouldn’t be in here.
It’s all gone crazy out there. Some daft woman flinging a sword about — (SEES TURLOUGH) Oh yeah? And who’s this?
I’m Turlough.
He’s been helping me. Well, sort of.
I saw you outside earlier, with that other lot.
You’re one of those protesters, aren’t you?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 70
Just standing up for what’s fair and right. (LOOKING AROUND, WHISTLES) Yeah, and I can see where the money went. All this gear must have cost a fortune!
It’s top secret, Barry. You shouldn’t be in here.
Why not? What have you got to hide? — Ohh, so that’s it, is it?
What’s what?
The reason the pair of you are looking so shifty.
I don’t look shifty.
Barry, I haven’t the faintest idea what you’re on about.
You’re not carrying on with this public school pillock, are you, Philippa? Not him as well!
What?
Barry — no.
Well, what else am I supposed to think?
There’s only you, Bazza.
Do I take it you two are having some sort of — (DISTASTE) — sordid affair?
Not that it’s any of your business, Eton boy, but yeah.
Brendon, actually.
Same difference.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 71
Oh, it’s all such a mess.
I take it the Professor didn’t know?
No, of course not.
Hang about — what do you mean, ‘didn’t’? You’ve not got that woman out there to — you know, do him in?
What? For you? Don’t be absurd.
The fact is, Barry, the Professor — poor, unsuspecting cuckold that he is — got taken off to who knows where by your girlfriend’s time machine.
You’re kidding.
Yes, thank you, Turlough. Really helpful.
Philippa, tell me he’s joking. You’ve invented a time machine?
Yes.
And... it works?
Like a dream, it seems. So far she’s dispatched the Professor and my friend Tegan into the mists of time.
So that mad woman outside...?
Comes from the tenth century.
(LAUGHING) This is priceless!
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 72
31: EXT. PHYSICS DEPT
FX: ELFWYN WHIRLING SWORD ABOUT — GASPS FROM PROTESTORS.
Arm yourself, demon master! Or make peace with your Gods!
Elfwyn, please. You can’t do this.
I’1l second that.
Only the Doctor can help you. Only he can get you back to your own time!
And if I can, I will. I promise!
A FEW FEET AWAY.
(TROTTING OVER) Professor Fester! Professor Fester! How are you enjoying it?
Enjoying it-?
Why, the re-enactment. That one must be Queen Ethelfrid, I presume.
Ohh, it’s a re-enactment! Of course, stupid of me. It’s all gone a bit talky and boring, though. (CALLING OVER) Go on, girl! Kill him!
SHUSH HIM
It’s a re-enactment, you fools! (CALLING) Do it! Hack his head off!
(ENTHUSIASTICALLY) Yeah!/ Go on!/ Do it!/ Knock his block off!
THROUGH THIS, CROSS BACK TO:
This is a barbaric place I find myself in.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 73
Welcome to the University of Frodsham, in the twentieth century. It’s Elfwyn, isn’t it?
Princess Elfwyn.
(BOWING) Your highness. I am the Doctor.
You are a brave man to bow before me.
Or a foolhardy one.
I have neither friends nor allies in this terrible land.
Well, now you have us.
Then — Doctor — I will return your courtesy. I shall trust you, I think.
In which case, let’s get back to the lab. Nyssa, hold the doors for her highness, would you?
FX: AS DOORS SWING OPEN, CROSS BACK TO:
GROAN, DISAPPOINTED
I think it must be finishing...
I’m not sure what was supposed to be going on. Were the students part of it?
Perhaps they represented the peasantry? The... ‘oi-polloi’?
FX: POLICE SIREN IN DISTANCE, APPROACHING
Oh dear. It sounds like some credulous idiot’s called the police.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 74
32: INT. CASTLE — DUNGEON
FX: WIND WHISTLING OUTSIDE. RATTLE OF KEYS IN CELL LOCK.
DOZING
(ENTERING) Professor Bleak... Bleak! Get with it, you drongo!
(WAKING) What’s up? — Oh no. Still here.
Come on, it’s almost dawn. We’re leaving.
We are-? (SEEING TEGAN’S ARMOUR) What on Earth are you wearing?
Exactly what every well-dressed woman warrior of the tenth century ought to be wearing.
You certainly look the part. Are we escaping?
Not exactly.
(DISAPPOINTED) Oh.
You remember how Ethelfrid’s only daughter disappeared with the time machine? Well, I’m standing in for her. Meet the new Princess Elfwyn.
Oh, good God. Why in heaven’s name did you go and commit yourself to this?
To save your sorry hide, Bleak. So if you want me to change my mind —
No, no! It’s just — Tegan, don’t you see how insanely dangerous this is?
And there was me thinking it’d be a doddle.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 75
But if they find you out — you’re dead.
You’re spoiling the fun, Prof.
At least you’re an expert on the era. Your historical knowledge might be your saving grace.
Uh... I’ve got news for you. I’m no academic.
Then what were you doing at my conference?
I don’t think that matters now, does it? Come on, you’ve got to get ready, as well.
What? Why?
I’m not leaving you alone here. You’re coming to York with the Royal entourage.
I don’t think so.
We’re late already. Get a move on.
All I want is to go home... and we can’t even do that now, with the machine gone. Oh, it’s hopeless! We’re going to die here, before we’ve even been born.
Buck up, Bleaky. You’ve always wanted to see history up close, haven’t you?
Not this close. Not actually taking part. I never wanted to be locked up and sleeping in filth and dressing up...
Tough. Because that’s what time travel is like.
How would you know?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 76
Look, I’ve asked the Queen if you can be my personal servant.
Your what?
So you’re coming on the road with us. Right now!
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 77
33: INT. PHYSICS LAB
Cheer up, Phils. You’re a single woman, and with an invention like this — you’re going to be rich!
I wasn’t in it for the money, Barry.
I know, money can’t buy you love, love. That’s where I come in, right?
(REVOLTED) Oh, please.
FX: DOOR FLIES OPEN. IN HURRIES THE DOCTOR AND NYSSA — AND THE
WARY ELFWYN.
It’s all right, we’re back.
Yeah, only you’ve brought the mad woman.
Has she calmed down yet?
My name is Elfwyn of Mercia. Don’t antagonize me, worm.
Dr Stone — I think we’d better do our best to get that machine of yours operational again, don’t you?
Hold on — who are you to go round giving me orders?
I’m offering you my help.
I don’t want it.
You should. The Doctor knows what he’s talking about.
And Philippa doesn’t? Look, I don’t know who you lot are, but Philippa here’s managed to build something no-one else ever has
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 78
Just leave it, Barry. I don’t need you to speak up for me.
That’s you told, Barry.
Cease this prattle! I command you to return me to my rightful place... at once!
That’s precisely what we’re endeavoring to do, your highness. If we can all just work together...
I agreed to follow you back into this place, Doctor. You only just escaped the taste of my blade, but I can renew my threat at any moment.
Yes, I appreciate that.
Wow — she’s the real deal, isn’t she?
A complete and utter barbarian.
I can repair the machine myself. Only I know how it operates, after all.
Well, I would have thought it was fairly obvious how it operates — wouldn’t you, Nyssa?
It scans an historical object, such as Ethelfrid’s sword, in four dimensions, then tries to latch onto the time trace of that object?
Primitive, of course, but everything’s more or less in the right place. —
Fix it! Now!
Can you do it — Doctors? Together?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 79
DOCTOR/STONE: (TOGETHER) Yes! (BEAT) But...
Here we go.
. It’1ll take several days, that’s all.
Days?
Well, probably.
(ASIDE) Doctor, I don’t think our royal friend here is prepared to wait that long.
(ASIDE) No. So I think the best thing all round would be if we were to (QUIETER) slip quietly back to the TARDIS... with the Princess, of course.
What was that?
We're taking Elfwyn back in the TARDIS.
The what?
Our own time machine.
Your own...?!
No time to discuss it now. Things to do. Your Majesty — this way, please.
You are very strange people.
You’re not wrong there.
This machine of yours, Doctor. Please — you have to show me.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 80
Dr Stone — you’re just not ready for this, I’m afraid. And you've proved that today already. Now, I suggest you stay here and, with respect, stop interfering with things you don’t understand.
You patronising...!
Doctor, that was rather rude.
I’m sorry, but we don’t have time for niceties. Turlough, you stay here and keep an eye on Dr Stone. Make sure she doesn’t complicate things further.
You think she’ll listen to me?
Princess Elfwyn — this way.
If you can keep your promise — very well.
FX: DOORS AS DOCTOR, NYSSA & ELFWYN EXIT.
Well, Dr Stone. (SARCASTIC) Shall I make the tea again?
Barry, make the tea.
What?
Go on. (TO TURLOUGH) Your Doctor wasn’t having us on, then, Turlough? About this ‘TARDIST’, or whatever he called it.
No. (BEAT) Why?
You know a thing or two about it, then?
Well — yes...
Good. Then you can help me fix my time machine, can’t you?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 81
Ohh no —
FX: PROTESTERS BEGINNING CHANTING OUTSIDE, CONFRONTED BY
POLICE.
(OFF) Down, down, down, down — down with the Laws of Physics! Two, four, six, eight - we can’t afford to cogitate!
Why have that lot started up again?
Hang about, I’1ll have a look. (FX: PULLING SLATS OF VENETIAN BLIND) Oh no. It’s the fuzz!
Oh, so the police turned up at last!
Yeah, and my lot don’t look like they’re ready to move along. I’d best go sort it out.
You do that, Barry.
FX: BARRY HURRIES OUT.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 82
34: EXT. CASTLE
FX: DAWN TWEETS. SNORTING OF HORSES — CLAD IN ARMOUR, READY FOR
THE OFF. TEGAN AND BLEAK WALKING UP.
I still can’t believe this is happening. Yesterday I was fretting over name badges and room bookings and overhead projectors, and now —
Shut up and saddle up.
Me? On a horse?
What did you expect — a coach trip? Riding’s easy. I learned on my Dad’s sheep farm. (2 x FX TO MATCH AS THEY BOTH MOUNT
) Look — right foot in stirrup — (EFFORT) — then push up and over — so!
FX: BLEAK’S HORSE PROTESTS.
Steady.
This isn’t a canter around a sheep farm — we’re headed into,
well, a war zone!
FX: ETHELFRID AND 2 x SOLDIERS APPROACHING.
Quiet. Here comes Ethelfrid. — Good morning, your Majesty.
Good morning... daughter. (TO SOLDIERS) You men — help me up.
FX: AS SOLDIERS HELP ETHELFRID MOUNT HORSE:
(ASIDE) Are they even going to be able to get her up on that
horse?
She looks frailer than she did last night.
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 83

That may be so, but there is nothing wrong with my hearing! (MOUNTED NOW) And here I am. Secure on my mount. Ready to face my people, with my daughter by my side. (RAISING VOICE, RALLYING TROOPS) We ride to York!
FX: 8 x HORSES JINGLING, STAMPING — MOVING OFF, THROUGH:
(SETTING OFF, SOTTO) Tegan, what are we doing? We’re becoming part of history!
(SETTING OFF, SOTTO) Yeah. But I don’t see how we can stop it — can you?
THE LADY OF MERCIA by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 84
35: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: TARDIS DOORS OPEN — HUMMING OF INTERIOR AND CONTROLS — AS
DOCTOR, ELFWYN AND NYSSA ENTER.
(LOOKING AROUND) What manner of wizardry is THIS?
(GOING TO CONSOLE) Nyssa — could you do the honours, while I get on with setting our destination?

BRIEF GRAPPLE
Page

DISMOUNTING CART) Brave heart — er, Nyssa. (ALOUD, TO ARTHUR

ROARS HUGELY — LIKE AN ENRAGED ANIMAL. OVER THIS:

PLATE ACROSS TABLE.
